bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 166, Number 163 (Monday, September 21, 2020)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. McCAUL:H.R. 8329.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, section 8 of the Constitution of the UnitedStates[Page H4642]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.

summary.text:
Revitalizing Multilateral Export Control Diplomacy for Critical Technologies Act

This bill requires the President to develop unified export control policies to eliminate or reduce the global availability of certain critical technologies to U.S. arms embargoed countries, and it establishes the Critical Technology Export Control Fund to support the development of these policies in coordination with U.S. allies and partners. Further, the bill requires the Department of Commerce to take specified actions related to reducing the reliance of the global semiconductor supply chain on U.S. arms embargoed countries.

bill.title: Revitalizing Multilateral Export Control Diplomacy for Critical Technologies Act

item.title: Revitalizing Multilateral Export Control Diplomacy for Critical Technologies Act
Revitalizing Multilateral Export Control Diplomacy for Critical Technologies Act
To eliminate or substantially reduce the global availability of critical technologies to United States arms embargoed countries, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
